Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is not clear where the information about the prevalence of domestic violence comes from.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the definition of domestic violence used by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is universally accepted and accurate.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations or factors that contribute to the statistics provided, which are not explored in the claim.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not providing a comprehensive analysis of the different types of domestic violence and their prevalence rates.
Understate: The claim may understate the issue of domestic violence by focusing only on severe physical violence and not considering other forms of abuse.
Exaggerate: It is unclear whether the claim exaggerates the prevalence of domestic violence as the source of the information is not provided.
Contradict fact: There is no clear contradiction of fact in the claim.
